text:
We all enjoyed these for breakfast with sliced strawberries and whipped cream. The only thing I do differently is make waffles in the blender.  First I whip up the egg in the blender then add the rest of the wet ingredients and blend quickly.  Then add the mixed dry ingredients to the blender and use the stir cycle until well mixed. Then I pour it directly onto the waffle iron.  I add extra milk to thin out the batter if it needs it.  Easy! and a nice treat.  Enjoy.

text:
My family liked this recipes I did make some alterations to the mix, I add 5 Tbls of sugar and 1 1/4 stick of real butter (melted) and about 3 Tbls of vanilla I know from past mistakes when cooking other recipes the bread didn't come out to sweet. This is a nice sweet I know it sounds like alot of sugar but it all balances out. I will definately use this recipe again!

text:
The only thing I did different than the directions stated to do was I sifted the flour, baking power & sugar before I added the liquid ingredients.  If we could my husband and I would give this a 10 star rating. Also remember to put the hot waffle on paper towels because otherwise they do get steamy/soggy without. Thank you for the wonderful recipe.. no more mixes for us!! YUMMO (just like Rachel Ray says) ;-)

city:

country:

text:
I've made this recipe twice now. Now never even eating anything but Eggos and hubby buying me a waffle maker for Christmas, the first time I made this recipe I following the directions exactly and they were good but they weren't "OMG these are amazing!" ... Which is why I gave this 4 stars.. Today I made this recipe again but this time I followed the suggestions in the reviews.. I used 4 tablespoons sugar, 1 tablespoon vanilla, 1/2 cup of butter (1 stick) just b/c it's easier than have a alittle bit of butter left over to put away in the fridge, and 1 3/4 cup milk to make it just alittle easier to pour. Today's batch was amazing!!! What a difference! Now it's a 5 star recipe! And everyone wanted more! Also... another tip.. The first time I made this I shifted the flour and I beat the egg whites and yolks separately to make fluffier waffles b/c that's all you see online about how to make fluffy waffles. But it was alot of work so today I didn't do any of that and they were the same texture/fluffiness, so don't waste your time doing those extra steps. ENJOY!!!

text:
What went wrong?!? I made these waffles exactly as the recipe said and they were limp and soggy, even after laying them out on a paper towel, and they tasted heavily of salt and baking soda. I was very disappointed because all the reviews made them sound wonderful.  

Conspiracy Theory: I've gone through the reviews for this recipe and the "too much baking soda" complaint is restricted to the last three reviews. I wonder if someone hacked into the recipe database and changed the amount of baking soda in the recipe so that poor, unsuspecting cooks would have their waffles ruined. Breakfast-related mayhem ensues and the evil hacker goes on to mess up other recipes. Think about it.

text:
Having never made a waffle until now, and having never even eaten one other than an Eggo, I have no basis to compare this recipe with any other.  Having said that, all I know is hubby and I enjoyed our breakfast this morning! In comparing this recipe with other similar recipes, including the one included in the manual, this one called for twice the amount of salt, so I reduced it by half keeping all other ingredients and measurements the same, and beat the eggs well to lighten them up. The waffle was crispy on the outside, but tender on the inside, with good flavor. My only criticism, and certainly no fault of the recipe, is that my waffle maker anyway, cooks unevenly, with some parts of the waffle browning more than others. Maybe it just takes practice spreading the batter?

text:
Wow! Perfect recipe for "Classic Waffles"!  I got a waffle maker and couldn't wait to try it out. They were crispy on the outside and tender on the inside. This recipe is perfect as-is, but if you want a sweeter waffle you can up the sugar to as much as you like. I upped it to about 4-6 Tbsp and was liberal with the vanilla. These are delicious topped with real maple syrup or fresh fruit and whipped cream!

text:
The first time I made these, they were a little bland.  I added 1t of cinnamon and used real butter this time, and they were outstanding.  Crispy, light, and full of flavor.  The best waffles I've made :)  They stay crispier if you pull them to one plate to cool slightly, then move them to another.  The steam condenses on the first plate.  I made them with home fries...yum!

Easy to make and delicious to eat. On most waffle irons, the waffle is "done" when the steam stops rising from the iron.

text:
These waffles are really good.  I've made them as is and I've made them with some adjustments.  As is, they are still very good, however I prefer my adjustments.  I added 1 tbsp of sugar and a dash of cinnamon.  I also separated the eggs and whipped the whites until stiff and folded them in last to make the waffles light and fluffy.  I also used 3/4 cup milk and 3/4 cup buttermilk instead of 1 1/2 cups milk.  Warmed the milk mixture, stirred it and then mixed it in with the eggs.  The waffles were awesome :)

text:
Very tasty!!  If you want the fluffiness of whipped egg whites without the work simply add a tablespoon or two of lemon juice.  The acid reacts with the baking powder already in the recipe and makes very fluffy waffles.

text:
Delicious.  For those stating the waffles became limp and soggy I suggest laying the waffles on a cooking rack to allow the excess moisture to evaporate for about 1-2 mins after baking them.  Also, make sure you are baking them thoroughly.  There is NO baking soda in this recipe; it calls for baking powder and the amount of baking powder is correct.  Happy baking.  This recipe is a keeper!

text:
This is a quick and easy recipe if you have a microwave (for the butter and milk)! I only omitted the vanilla, since I didn’t have any.  I also don’t have a waffle iron, so I made fat little pancake triangles in the sandwich maker! It works really well, and they are tasty and fully cooked through, despite the thickness.  I like that these are not too sweet, so you can add the condiment of your choice.  I am certainly going to be making these again, hopefully one day with a waffle iron. ;)

text:
Quick and easy.  Not as light as the egg separated/whipped whites version.  4 for taste/texture but 5 because of ease of prep.  Our 8 yr. old can make these on her own for us.  We found the batter on the thick side and upped the milk to 2c instead of 1.5c, and it was still plenty thick enough.  The standard recipe for 5 made 6 thick Belgian waffles for us.

text:
These are wonderful basic waffles.  I make them as per the recipe, but add cinnamon.  My kids love them with peanut butter and jam.  Trick to keeping the waffles crispy is to not put them immediately on a plate (the steam makes them soggy).  I throw waffles in warm oven for 10-15 seconds to allow the steam to rise off before putting them on plates.

None
text:
I was looking for a new waffle recipe and gave this one a try this morning. I added more Sugar (about 2 1/2 TBSP) but otherwise followed the recipe exactly. The waffles were light and fluffy with a nice golden "crust". I may add a touch more vanilla next time. Between that and the needed sugar this recipe is perfect! Also, one thing it took me a while to learn in making waffles - they NEVER turn out fully risen if I sprinkle things like blueberries or chocolate chips before closing the lid. It's a completely different waffle - so leave them plain and get creative with what you put on top of them when they are finished! Thanks for the recipe! This will be replacing my old one.

Display Name:
simply myself

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674135.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is awesome all on its own, but I like to play with recipes after trying them a few times.  I have since tweaked this recipe, and my husband and his family love it.  

Here are my substitutions:
Instead of 1 teaspoon salt, I use 1/2 teaspoon salt and 1/2 teaspoon baking soda.  I use 1/3 cup canola oil instead of butter (butter is really expensive here and melted margarine just didn't work right for us).  I use milk straight out of the fridge and don't bother with heating it.  I use 2 teaspoons of vanilla extract.

It's a little quicker to put together since nothing requires heating, and the waffles turn out beautifully.

text:
These are absolutely delish!! I made these for my 3 girls and husband on their first day of spring break and they loved them!! They turned out picture perfect! I started by making one batch which wasn't enough for my size family so I made a double batch on top of the batch I had already made which was way to much. So I came up with an idea to keep making them until all the batter was gone then put them in a zip lock bag then pop them in the refrigerator for the next morning. THIS WAS THE BEST IDEA IN THE WORLD!!! The next day I pulled them out of the fridge and popped them in the toaster, DELICIOUS!!!!! I will be using this recipe for years and years and years to come!!! Thanks so much for posting!!!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/661917.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've eaten waffles before but never made them for myself at home. The batter was easy to put together, thou I only added 1/2 tsp of salt. I also increased the sugar to 3T. I did whip the eggs separately then added it to the batter last before pouring onto the hot waffle maker. I used PAM non-stick cooking spray in between each batch so the waffles wouldn't stick. This batch makes 12 waffles, half of which I froze for another day. The waffles didn't take that long to cook and is a nice golden brown color. The waffle is crispy on the outside, but soft on the inside. It is also tasty and has a good flavor. My family and I enjoyed these for breakfast this morning with fresh sliced strawberries and light drizzle of maple syrup. Now that I know how to make waffles, I think next time I would like to top this off with some homemade whipped topping.

text:
I quickly found this recipe and didn't look at any reviews or suggestions, assuming with so many reviews and the high star rating it would be excellent.  Unfortunately I found the waffles dry and tasteless. The batter was VERY thick and I didn't take the time to thin it with milk, assuming it was supposed to be this way to maintain the flavor.  My daughters ate them but we found they were MUCH improved with blueberries, butter and something to dip them in like syrup or vanilla yogurt.  I would rather have had a delicious tasting waffle that could almost stand alone on it's taste.  The ONLY thing I changed was using King Arthur White Wheat flour, which I use for everything.  Perhaps this was the problem.  Needless to say I am very disappointed and next time will read more.  I won't be making these again.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/871418.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made these tonight to be rewarmed in the toaster oven in the morning. I didn't separate the yolks from the whites, but I beat the eggs pretty well before adding the other liquids. I also made sure that the butter had cooled before adding so that it didn't cook the egg. The waffles browned very well and raised well. They were also light on the inside. I didn't crisp them because that would be done in the toaster oven. I doubled the recipe, and will freeze the leftovers for future quick breakfasts. One word of caution I can offer is to be careful not to add too much batter to the waffle maker, and to spread the batter a bit before closing the waffle maker. The first couple of waffles made a mess all over the counter with the run-off. This is not the fault of the recipe, but the batter does spread and raise a lot.

text:
I made two seperate batches of this recipe, exactly according to the recipe. It was the weirdest thing, one batch was really thick and one was much thinner. Either way, the waffles turned out crisp on the outside and fluffy and soft on the inside. From the thick batch, I got exactly eight waffles. From the thin batch, I was able to get nine. My husband says this needs to be my go-to waffle recipe from now on. I was making one that used oil instead of butter but he and I both agreed that butter makes all the difference.

madeRecipesCount:
8
favoritesCount:
72
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/723660.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've been using this recipe for a year now. The first time I made it as is but now I make it with a few changes. I use 1 3/4 cup milk because, as written, the batter is too thick. 1 3/4 c seems a little runny at first but I always let my batter rest for 5-7 min after mixing and by then it has thickened nicely.

I use 6 T of butter since that's easier to measure than 5 1/3 T(which is 1/3 c). I also use 4 tbsp sugar  and 2tbsp vanilla. Instead of using 2c all-purpose, I use 1 c All-purpose and 1 c white whole wheat flour(King Arthur or Gold Medal brands).  

If you've never tried white whole wheat then you should. It's gives you all the benefits of red wheat but none of red wheat's bitterness. I use it to get in extra fiber in many of baked goods I make for my family. That's the beauty of cooking from scratch!

city:

country:
None
text:
So... amazing... I followed the recipe but for one change: I used margarine instead of butter. And these turned out absolutely delicious. Some reviewers suggest separating the eggs, beating the whites and folding in gently at the end. While I'm sure this makes for an even fluffier waffle, I don't feel it's necessary. These were fluffy, light, crispy. The batter seemed a little runny at the end, so I added a couple tablespoons of cornstarch (as recommended by my waffle iron manual to make waffles more crispy), but as the batter sat between waffles, it got a lot thicker. It was unnecessary, but my waffles WERE nice and crispy! Thanks for sharing, Megan!

country:
None
text:
This recipe is unshakeable.  I'm not one to substitute a bunch of ingredients and then give a bad review, but I'm happy to report that this recipe stands up to all kinds of substitutions.  I've used oil instead of butter, rice milk, hemp milk, and/or almond milk instead of milk, egg substitute instead of eggs, and I think I've even used alternative flours.  I've been cooking to accommodate a lot of food allergies.  The only time this recipe hasn't turned out well for me was when I didn't finish melting the butter as the recipe says.  Enjoy and don't be afraid to substitute ingredients based on allergies or kitchen shortages.

I just made these for our Christmas breakfast and they were PERFECT!!  I separated my eggs to I could whip my egg whites until soft peaks then added the yokes and the rest of the wet ingredients (I added an extra 1/4 cup of milk because it was pretty thick) I also cut the baking powder by 1/2 tsp.  If you don't have baking powder you can use baking soda and cream of tarter(I ran out out of "powder" but the conversion of the other two worked perfectly)

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674145.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wow these waffles are perfect!  I followed the recipe ingredients exactly, except I sift the flour and baking powder.  If people are complaining that these are too salty, it may be from clumpy baking powder.  Make sure you sift and mix all the dry ingredients well so the powder and salt are evenly distributed.  Another tip is to make sure you know how to use your waffle iron.  I recently was gifted one, and never made them before so i made this batter, poured it on the iron and promptly closed it, resulting in batter gushing out.  The trick is not to overflow and to leave the iron open after pouring on the batter so the bottom side cooks a little first, reducing splatter and gushing onto your counters!

This recipe is easy and delicious. I used the exact ingredients. The only change I made was to use another reviewer's suggestion of mixing it in a blender, beating the eggs first, then added the remaining liquid ingredients. Then slowly added the dry ingredients in batches. The waffles were light and crispy. I will never use the box mix again for waffles at my house.

I made 1.5 recipes and it yielded 16 single waffles or 8 double. I am on a sodium reduced diet, I used 3 tsps baking powder, 3/4 tsp baking soda and omitted the salt. I added 1/4 tsp cinnamon and halved the butter as well, enjoyed by my family.

Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2013-06-10T16:43:21.223
helpfulCount:

userID:
11516195
Display Name:
busymomof3
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674156.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great recipe! I made two batches. The first batch I made exactly as recipe stated and they were wonderful. I made a second batch (because I love to experiment) and added 2 additional tbs of sugar and an additional tsp of vanilla. We loved them even more, however I am always generous with my vanilla so that addition suited us better. I doubled the recipe for my family of 5 and froze the left overs for quick do-it-yourself breakfasts for the kids. I have read several reviews some complaining of too much salt and others complaining of a lack of crispiness. Please make sure you are using baking powder, not baking soda. Also, I always use unsalted butter. Real butter comes salted or unsalted, so adjust the salt according to the type of butter used. My waffles were crispy (and I love them  very crispy), but the key to that maybe having a well heated waffle iron.

text:
BEST. WAFFLES. EVER. After many years of Eggo waffles and different premade mixes, I decided it was time to make REAL waffles. These are literally the best things I have ever tasted! However, being the kind of person I am, I used applesauce instead of butter, only 1/8 t. of salt, honey instead of sugar, and whole wheat flour instead of all-purpose. With a it of real maple syrup on the side, it turned out to be a fantastic breakfast. Definitely making them again!

region:

country:

text:
I received a waffle iron/griddle for my wedding 15 years ago.  I used to make waffles every Saturday for my family, until my kitchen flooded and my griddle (being kept under the sink) was damaged due to being immersed in water.  This was several years ago.  I *finally* got a new waffle iron and was excited to make waffles again...  I used this recipe based on the rating and the comments, but rather than make changes right off, I decided to do the recipe EXACTLY AS WRITTEN so that I would be able to do a fair review.  I followed this recipe exactly as written, and the waffles were very crispy and fluffy and wonderful EXCEPT I found them to be TOO SALTY. So I could only give 4 stars.  I imagine if one was to reduce the salt by about 1/2 it would be absolutely perfect, so all in all a really great waffle recipe!

country:
None
text:
I made this "as is" and was not impressed. It was bland and heavy. I made it again adding a Tbsp of white vinegar to the milk, added a tsp of cinnamon and following others advice, increased sugar to 5 Tbsp and increased vanilla to 2 Tbsp. It definitely was not too sweet but I still was not impressed as it was very heavy. If I use it again I will probably separate the eggs, beat in the egg yolk, whip the whites in a separate bowl and fold them in to see if it lightens the texture. Honestly, I am hard to please with waffle recipes but I miss the down South "Waffle Ho*se" flavor and texture of their waffles and want to reproduce that!

These turned out very nicely for us. I veganized them by using soy milk (in place of cow's milk) and flaxseed/water mix (in place of the eggs). I also made them a bit lower fat (maybe even fat free!) by using applesauce (blueberry applesauce to be exact) in place of the melted butter.

text:
Wonderful! I did alter it a bit, following what some other reviewers did - I like waffles sweet, so I added a couple of extra tablespoons of sugar and I added an extra teaspoon of vanilla. I also replaced the butter with 1/3 c of applesauce and I separated the eggs, folding in the whites last. These were delicious! I'd definitely make them again! (Norwegian Waffles from this site are my other favorite!)

This is a perfect waffle recipe!  My oldest son made them yesterday (May 18) for my birthday breakfast.  He doubled the recipe and it made 6 full-sized waffles.  He added 1-1/3 cups chocolate chips to the batter, and that made them even yummier!  A great way to satisfy a chocolate craving!  I agree with other reviewers about making extras and freezing them for a later meal.  Then all you have to do is pop them in the toaster or microwave to heat them up.  Definitely less expensive than buying frozen waffles at the grocery store!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674154.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These were really good!  I took two recommedations from others:  1) separate the egg whites and yolks.  With a hand mixer, beat the yolks and the other liquid ingredients together, and then beat it together with the dry ingredients. In a separate dish, beat the egg whites until thick. FOLD the egg whites into the rest of the mixture and you're ready to go!  I think this did make a difference, making the waffles nice and thick.  2) Put the waffles on paper towel for a minute when finished cooking to absorb the moisture.  I had never done that before and I think that helped too! I did make one other change, and put in an extra tsp of vanilla.  These turned out great and the flavor was wonderful!  Will definitely make again!

text:
This is a great recipe with one minor change. Instead of beating the whole egg with the milk and butter, I only mixed the egg yolks and then mixed into the batter. The egg whites I set aside and then beat them separately until stiff and then folded into the batter. This made the waffles fluffier.

text:
Ok, after years of trying to find a good waffle recipe, I have found it!! Made some for a lunch treat for the kids and they all want to give it 5 stars-so with 5 kids, that is like 25 stars-lol! They are crspy on the outside and tender on the inside. I didn't have vanilla, so added cinnamon and they were still tasty! My waffle maker makes 4 large size waffles at once (in one big square) and I was able to refill the waffle maker 3 times, resulting in 12 nice sized waffles for us. I will double or triple this recipe and make a huge batch to put up in the freezer! Thanks!!

text:
I made this today for six people, including three teenagers, so I multiplied the quantities by 50% and had just enough.  I also served some eggs to go with the waffles (served with mixed berries, maple syrup and whipping cream).  I also took the suggestion from the comments to add more sugar and vanilla extract.  I made the waffles in a Cuisinart 4x waffle maker set on "4" and they turned out very well. Much easier than the traditional way that uses yeast.  This recipe is a keeper in my books - not buying any pre-made mixes anymore.

Very good waffle recipe. These waffles turned out buttery and perfect. I made some whipped cream and fresh berries to serve on top.  I saw a comment that said it tasted of baking soda, so I wanted to comment that that is probably where they made their mistake. The recipe calls for baking powder NOT baking soda. I made them for her 12th birthday breakfast.   Really good stuff.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674139.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These waffles are AWESOME. 

To up the awesome factor:
*Do not make the mistake of using baking soda instead of baking powder. They are not the same thing and are not interchangeable. 
*Add more sugar - I used 5 T
*Add more vanilla - I used about 1 T
* Mix in a heaping spoonful of malted milk powder with the other dry ingredients 
* Add in some maple extract for kicks and giggles

When I tweaked this recipe, I made the best waffles I have ever had. Omm nom nommm...

text:
We had these for supper tonight - one of those great "breakfast for dinner" meals!  They mixed up quick and easy and turned out perfect. My only complaint is that the recipe says it makes 10-12 waffles - so based on that I cut the recipe in half as it's just the two of us.  I only got 3 waffles, so I have no idea what size waffle they are talking about.  It was just enough since I had plenty of other breakfast foods to go with them.  At least I now know I would have to double this recipe to get a dozen waffles.  I will use this recipe again for sure.

text:
Stephanie's variation on this recipe makes it 5 stars! I'm a breakfast fanatic and these are the best waffles, bar none, that I've ever made...or eaten! (I don't recommend whole wheat flour or whole wheat blends as it makes them a bit heavy). Stick to "all purpose flour". Thanks, again, to Stephanie whose variation is below. 

{Stephanie's Variant:
My family liked this recipes I did make some alterations to the mix, I add 5 Tbls of sugar and 1 1/4 stick of real butter (melted) and about 3 Tbls of vanilla I know from past mistakes when cooking other recipes the bread didn't come out to sweet. This is a nice sweet I know it sounds like alot of sugar but it all balances out.} I will definately use this recipe again!

text:
I got a waffle maker for my birthday yesterday. I wanted a simple recipe to try it out with as the recipe that came with the waffle maker involved yeast and I wanted waffles RIGHT NOW, not when the yeast decided to proof. This was the first time I've ever made waffles and I really don't think I have to search any further for a different recipe, this one is a keeper for sure! 

I took suggestions from other reviewers and added a bit more sugar (four tablespoons rather than two) and I beat the egg whites separately and folded them into the batter. You'd think I've been making waffles all my life! They came out fluffy and golden brown. They do go soggy very quickly though -eat immediately! I'm going to try freezing and toasting them. I may never have to buy another box of Eggos again! I'm thinking of making country gravy with fried chicken and waffles next. I can hardly wait!

I followed the recipe with a few modifications I increased the sugar to 3 teaspoons and the vanilla to 2 teaspoons. I separated the eggs and just before starting to cook the waffles I whipped the whites to a stiff foam and folded them in to the batter. I served them with a large ring of whipped cream around the sides and the center full of strawberries, blueberries and blackberries. everyone commented on the taste of the waffels. didn't say much about the topping.  a great recipe. text:
Tried this recipe this morning with one addition; bacon!! I like the precooked Hormel (just faster and doesn't make a mess) that is microwaved.  I put 1/2 c in the center of a 4 squared waffle cooker, and added about 3 pieces (broken up) on the top of the uncooked waffle dough, put the top down and just cooked it for about 2 minutes.  The bacon is crushed into the middle of the waffle and it just like the way my parents made it when I was growing up.  Takes me back to childhood.... butter & syrup, yummy.

text:
I hadn't made waffles in a long time, but when we moved recently I found my waffle iron and got excited. This recipe is perfect. I did make one minor change to the ingredients by using melted extra-virgin coconut oil in place of the butter. I mixed this up in my Ninja Master Prep and then poured directly into the hot waffle iron. They cooked up perfectly crisp on the outside and tender on the inside -just like the name implies. The flavor was fantastic as well. This recipe made exactly twelve 4x4" square waffles. My family of six demanded a second batch. :)

Display Name:
lin

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614284.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love this recipe, but afterwards I used a little bit different ingredients.  I used one cup of whole wheat pastry flour, 1/2 cup of all purpose flour, and 1/2 cup of quinoa flour.  I also used melted coconut oil instead of butter, and used one tablespoon of sugar and one tablespoon of stevia, and added some cinnamon.  They came out really light, fluffy and yummy.  Another time I added two tablespoons of vinegar to the warm milk which caused the waffles to be even lighter and fluffier, and taste a bit buttermilkish.  When we aren't eating up all the waffles at once I take the remaining ones and immediately put them on a plate and pop them into the freezer.  Once they are frozen I put them in a freezer bag.  When we want them again we take them out of the freezer and heat them up in the toaster over.  They come out just as warm, crunchy, and yummy as they did before.  Everything I use is always organic which seems to keep us very healthy, and the quinoa flour gives us additional protein since we are ovo-lacto vegetarians.

text:
This recipe is OK. Way Too much baking powder and not enough sugar.  I do not like sweet anything, but this really needs more sugar.  Also, not enough vanilla extract.  I recommend letting the waffle rest on a cookie grid before plating, to let the steam escape as the plates will otherwise become very soggy.  I will definitely make a few alterations the next time I make this recipe.

text:
For those who are gluten free, I substitute a GF flour in place of the flour in the recipe and change nothing else and it's fantastic! Great texture - soft and dense. The batter is thick and more milk may or may not be required depending on where you live. With the batter, scoop a ladle full out and gentle press the top of your waffle machine on it and it's fine.

This recipe is just fine without the sugar.  I've substituted the eggs for mashed bananas when I don't have eggs on hand and they're just as good.  My son loves plain waffles so we often have left over batter in the fridge that keeps for a day or so.  
We tried these in our Belgian waffle maker and it didn't work very well but this recipe is perfect for the thin, crispy waffles.  
This is our favorite waffle recipe - you won't be disappointed!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1729901.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Perfect, buttery waffles. These are wonderful as is, and also lovely with a margarine instead of a butter. I mixed this using my blender, which made it a lot easier to pour into the waffle iron.

I'm not sure where the bland and/or salty reviews are coming from. The only thing I can see is that several people mention baking SODA when this recipe calls for baking POWDER. Baking soda is 3 or 4 times saltier than baking powder, and has a pretty foul taste when heated - it needs some kind of acid to neutralize it. Baking Powder does not need an additional acid in it, because it already has an acid built in. Regardless, make sure you use a baking POWDER and not a soda, or your waffles will taste pretty terrible.
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:

Love! The texture and the ease of this recipe is great- and it was very receptive to my fancying-up: we have been on a bit of a coconut kick lately, so I used coconut milk (the Silk kind, not the canned kind) instead of regular, used coconut extract instead of vanilla and tossed in about 1/2 cup shredded sweetened coconut (I also wasn't feeling all that butter so I substitited plain Greek yogurt for about half the quantity). LOVED these! Original recipe made 12 waffles (we made 1.5X for our family of 6, made 18). I added a little less baking powder (4 tsp for 1.5X), doubled the sugar (6 tbsp for 1.5X), didn't warm the milk (forgot) and beat the egg whites separately and folded them in at the end. Yum!!

This is a great recipe - no tweaking required!  I make a double batch, place slightly undercooked, cooled waffles on a cookie sheet, flash freeze, then place in ziplock freezer bags. text:
My family and I are big fans of pancakes & waffles so I've tried my fair share of recipes.  Can't believe how simple this recipes is both in ingredients & in prep but it delivers fantastic results!  I made exactly as written.  I think next I will add more vanilla but other than that they were fabulous.  I know some reviewers have suggested separating the eggs & whipping the whites...I wonder if they tried the recipe without doing that because I don't find that to be necessary with this recipe.  Just don't over mix - any recipes for pancakes or waffles will be tough if you over mix.  There SHOULD be some lumps.  Mix just enough to incorporate.  Enjoy your breakfast!

text:
I decided to make waffles for dinner (again) and tried out this recipe this time.  It's a perfect fit for us and our waffle maker.   It made 9 waffles in our waffle maker, which is a classic round.  I use 1/2 cup batter and this batter is thick enough that I didn't have a single spill-over, which I usually have with thinner batters.   The only change I made was to add cinnamon because I was serving these with toasted pecans, sliced banana, and maple syrup.  I just realized that I forgot to add the salt.  The recipe doesn't really need it and I use unsalted butter.

text:
I've tried many waffle recipes and this is my favorite with the best results... even compared to using bisquik which produces a "too heavy" belgian waffle with package directions. 

This tastes every bit like a "diner" style belgian waffle. has simple, inexpensive, common ingredients and is easy to prepare for kitchen newbies, and trouble free enough for an experienced cook to whip up quickly. 
5/5

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674163.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a good recipe to start with.  The only changes I made were to separate the egg whites from the yolks and beat them til they formed soft peaks.  After combining the flour, salt, baking powder, and sugar I added in the 2 egg yolks whisked with milk, butter and vanilla.  I mixed this well and then folded in the egg whites.  I also like to add frozen or fresh fruit such as blueberries and raspberries.  With the amount of butter in the recipe I find it is not necessary to spread butter over the waffles and instead just use warmed maple syrup.  Very good!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I think this recipe is overall very good and works well. Having read the reviews, the only reason they would be bland is if you left out the sugar or vanilla extract because I find them to be very flavorful each time.  However, having made them multiple times, I have found that there is not enough liquid in the batter, which causes the density that some people have complained about.  I up the amount of milk to just under 2 cups, which may seem to make the batter runny but creates an amazingly fluffy and crisp waffle.

text:
This is a great and simple recipe. We make it every Saturday morning. I tried beating the egg whites separately (to make it fluffier) but it doesn't make much of a difference and it's much faster to do it all at once. This is good in the fridge for a few days and tastes better if the batter is made the night before. I usually add a little bit of cinnamon and something else like blueberries or chocolate chips. I tried making it with whole wheat flour and a bit more milk for a healthy version but the original is better!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used this recipe as a base for a gluten free waffle. I used my own Gluten free flour blend. I used only a 1/2 tsp salt, and an extra tsp of baking powder and  a 1/2 tsp of cinnamon. I also separated the eggs and beat the whites until stiff but not dry and then folded them in to the rest of the batter. My waffles came out fluffy and crisp. which is hard to get with GF. I only gave it 4 stars since I change the recipe and have no idea what it would taste like made with normal wheat flour.

These were SO DELICIOUS! I added a little extra sugar for more flavor, but other than that I followed the recipes. They were light, very fluffy, and didn't sit heavily like store-bought mixes do. I highly recommend this for its simplicity and deliciousness!

text:
Crispy and light!!! I have tried many of the recipes on this site and we love this one the most so far(as of august 2010). I accidentally added another cup of milk and substituted olive oil for the butter and maple syrup for the sugar and I separated the whites of the eggs and whipped them and added them last, so I do not know if that is why we loved it, but we have been trying many recipes and this is the one my kids FINALLY said I should keep!!  Yay!! We eat ours with smoothies instead of syrup.  Waaaay more appetizing!  No ice in the smoothie- just yogurt, frozen fruit, 3-6-9 oils, juice if needed and sugar or maple syrup to sweeten if needed.  Then it is really thick and you can dip the waffle in the smoothie.

I thought these were good - alittle bland but the first try is always the basic recipe. An issue I had tho was (and I'm not sure this is a bad thing) the amount of steam/moisture that came from the batter when it was cooking. It made for a yummy crispy waffle but when I was cleaning the waffle pan water literally poured out from it. Maybe about 1/4 cup. I may have used skim milk I'm not completely sure if I did...Remade 6/5/12 - Have a new puppy :) Son helped me watch her when I put the batter together. Since I was in a bit of a time squeeze I didn't heat the milk and it sat in the fridge for a few hours before I actually made the waffles. Like this method much better. Still came out somewhat crispy (I probably could have let them cook longer) and fit into the little bits of time intervals that I had. Used whole milk this time around :)

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/327727.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I like these waffles, but I found them a bit bland and dense. So, I added 3 tsp of vanilla extract, and 3 to 4 Tbs of white sugar, and 2 cups of milk . The extra milk made the waffles less dense and lighter, and increased the number of waffles from 5 to 8, perfect for a family of 4 (2 waffles each). You can also make them ahead and freeze them so you can eat them whenever you want by reheating in the toaster. They're really good for a quick breakfast when you're in a hurry. Just toast, and take it with you because it's already sweet!! I also found that by adding extra sugar, they're sweet enough that you don't need as much syrup or you can eat them as is!!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have been looking for a grat waffle recipe for some time. I own the Kitchenaid proline waffle iron and many of them either turn out too thin and crispy or too soft.  These came out just right.  Crunchy exterior with a soft middle.    Tip: Be sure to use a cooling rack or the waffle will get soggy underneath.   Another tip: an easy way to reheat a waffle is just to use the waffle iron again for about 15 seconds. It reheats great if you are making for a large group and need to make ahead.  Better than using the oven which will dry them out.  Great stuff!

text:
My 11 yo son wants to learn how to cook and we made these waffles together. He love them! They are very good and are great to store in the fridge to toast for a quick breakfast! The only change I made was to beat the egg whites until soft peaks and add a touch bit more of sugar. He wanted pecan waffles so we chopped the nuts and added them into the batter also. I have a belgium waffle maker and it was perfect! I wanted to make several batches to freeze, but we ran out of eggs so it will have to wait for next weekend! Much better than store bought mixes! Thanks for sharing!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Okay, even though I completely butchered this recipe it surprisingly came out good!  I wasn't so sure about the amount of baking soda so I only put in 1 tsp. and that seemed to work just fine.  I already added the salt to the dry mix, and then I accidentally melted salted butter instead of unsalted, so instead of wasting the salted, I mixed in half of the salted with some unsalted.  If that wasn't bad enough, I realized I didn't have enough milk, so I ended up only putting in about 1 cup....and I forgot to warm it up!  So when I added the cold milk to the butter mixture...sure enough the butter turned back to halfway solid!!  So, I had chunks of butter all throughout this wet mixture.  I added it anyway to the dry ingredients and although it looked jacked up and was a very thick batter, I decided to put it in the waffle iron anyway.  I thought this would be terrible for sure, but I am pleased to say they still turned out!  They're especially good with syrup, strawberries and whip cream!

country:

text:
These waffles were surprisingly good.  Despite the 4.5 star rating they enjoy, we didn't expect too much when looking at the picture of brown waffles.  But seriously, these have good flavor and were a hit all around.  I mean they're waffles... worst case, throw the bisquick recipe together if these don't pan out... but they did.  We wanted a breakfast project, and these were it.  We didn't warm the milk (so the butter hardened up in the egg/milk mixture... no problem... and we sifted the flour mixture together.  All in all, a great looking/tasting waffle product.  We'll make these again if we get a hankering for non-Bisquick waffles again.

text:
Great waffles! I used the amount of baking powder in the recipe and increased the amount of sugar to 5 TBSP, a stick of butter, and doubled the vanilla. Make sure to cook the waffles throughly and let stand on a cooling rack for a minute or two...this will help them crisp up. Generally when I make pancakes or waffles the first one comes out wonky-- not with this recipe! Every waffle turned out fantastic!

text:
followed it exactly and they were great. for those reviews saying "tasted too much of baking soda" re read the recipe. it calls for baking POWDER, not soda. if you do not have POWDER, and want to substitute with soda, you have to reduce the amount  to half of what the recipe asks for, and also add an acidic component, like for example, buttermilk instead of milk, or just a tiny bit of vinegar

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I added an additional tsp of  baking powder, 4 tsp of corn starch, and changed the fat to 2 ounces melted butter plus 1 ounce canola oil.  I used 2% milk as that is what I keep in the house.  I beat the liquid ingredients with an immersion blender, whisked into the dry and then used the blender to whip it all up.  It made 4 waffles in my Black and Decker round Belgian waffle maker.  They were light and crispy.  Served with a warm syrup of blended pure maple syrup, cream cheese and butter.  Yum!  I have been considering ditching my inexpensive waffle maker and splurging on the Breville Smart Waffle maker... but this modified recipe might change my mind!

text:
The ingredients ratio is very good. I made some minor adjustments:
- mixed some buttermilk powder into the warm milk
- separated the York and white. Beat egg white with electric mixer and fold into the batter the last
- I preheated the waffle iron while making the batter. My problem before was the waffle iron was not hot enough. This time it really made a difference. 

The waffles turned out really delicious. Fluffy inside and crispy on the outside.

I’ve used many waffle recipes over the years, but this turned out to be one of the best I’ve ever tried. text:
Delicious and fluffy waffles. Turned out beautifully. The only changes I made was to substitute 1/3 cup oil for the melted butter, since I was out of butter. I also whipped the egg whites until stiff peaks and folded into the batter at the end as was suggested by some reviewers.  It made them perfectly fluffy. Next time I'll double the recipe as it just made 5 waffles in my Belgian waffle iron and I have a hungry family. I definitely will make it again!

text:
This is my go to recipe for waffles. I did change the recipe after reading some comments and making the first batch exactly as written. I made this with 5 Tbls. of sugar, 1/2 cup butter and 1 Tbls. of vanilla extract. We like things a little sweeter, so 5 Tbls. of sugar are just right for our family. This recipe makes 4 large waffles. Any leftovers get finished before the end of the day, everyone loves them.

text:
This was one of the best waffle recipe I’ve had!! I did make a couple happy adjustments though! I didn’t have eggs so I used flaxseed meal as a replacement (ratio 3 T of warm water to 1 T of flaxseed= 1 egg). I also added some cinnamon and a dash of nutmeg. I make waffles almost every weekend and this recipe by far was fantastic... buckle up ;)

text:
They were light and fluffy waffles.  I doubled the recipe and with my waffle maker it made 8 waffles.  Two that were eaten today and the rest layered with parchment paper.  Will bake in 350 degree oven for 15 mins  for breakfast at a later date.  I used a gluten free flour mix and warmed almond milk.  This is now my go to recipe for home made waffles.  So much better than the pre-made frozen waffles in the grocery store.

I read a much earlier review about possibly the recipe has to much baking soda and tasted horrible.  The recipe doesnt call for baking soda it is baking powder.

text:
I made the following changes. I used self raising flour, 4tbs white sugar, 2 sticks of butter.  I beat the eggs in one bowl. In another I beat the warmed milk and butter until very fluffy. I combine these two bowls, then add the combined dry ingredients to the wet. (Paul Hollywood recommends adding dry to wet rather than the other way ).

text:
I made these amazing fuffy waffles that were super golden and rich in taste. I did make a few changes. I separated the eggs and beat the egg whites until they were stiff peaks and folded them in just before I put them on my waffle iron. I added two teaspoons of vanilla extract instead of one. Overall I had eight amazing fluffy and crispy waffles. I will definitely use this recipe for all my future waffles.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love this recipe.  It has just the right amount of sweetness and vanilla as is for breakfast. Per a review, I did separate the eggs, added the yolks with the wet ingredients and folded in the whites at the end.  It gave the waffles a light, airy texture.  I also wanted to add that the recipe would have had 5 Stars if it had any kind of time and temperature guidelines.  I have a Bella 8-1.  Per instructions, I wiped the plates with vegetable oil prior to cooking, preheated it to 400F and cooked for 7 minutes.  6 is adequate if you want to freeze them and toast them later. Didn't stick and didn't make a mess of my Bella.

This is one of those "everyone should have" recipes.

Two notes:

2. The recipe lends itself to spice as well. I added 1 tsp of cinnamon and it amped up the flavor marvelously.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Phenomenal waffles! Never buying Eggo again! Like other reviewers suggested, I upped the milk to 1 3/4 cups, the sugar to four tablespoons, and the butter to 1/2 cup. In addition, I also added 1 tablespoon of vanilla extract and 1-2 teaspoons of cinnamon. Flavor. Explosion! The cinnamon adds a wonderful hint of flavor! Beforehand, I had never made waffles before, and now I make them nearly every weekend! Tip: if you’re looking for fluffy waffles that are also crispy on the outside, instead of whisking your whole eggs together, only include the egg yolks in the wet mixture and set aside the egg whites. After you’ve combined the wet and dry mixture, whip the egg whites to stiff peaks and fold the, into your waffle mixture. It makes a world of a difference!

So I reviewed this recipe earlier and said it was way too salty. It turns out that due to a kitchen mishap, we had some salt get mixed in with our sugar, and that is why the recipe was so salty. I thought it was strange because I had made a half recipe a week earlier with some modifications and it was fine. I will mention that the Betty Crocker waffle recipe calls for 1/4 the salt. I may stick with that.

I thought that 4 tsp was going to be too much and I was 100% correct. So the waffles end up being slightly bitter and you can't taste the butter or vanilla at all.  I ended up ending some spices after the first one to give them flavor but nothing could help the bitterness.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2794496.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I did everything as directed, however I only added the egg yolks when instructed to add eggs. I separated the egg whites and beat them until they formed stiff peaks, then folded them in gently as my last step. I added pecans and pb chips to my first batch, and the batter stood up to them very well. Slightly denser than the recipe I typically use, but it makes for a crispier waffle fresh out of the waffle iron. I put my waffles in the oven at about 300 to keep them warm while making them, and these don't sog up, which I've had a problem with using other recipes. All in all, my new go-to!

country:

text:
This is a fantastic and simple recipe. I have seen several negative complaints about them tasting of baking soda.  THERE IS NO BAKING SODA IN RECIPE it is baking POWDER.  I can see why it was a fail.

I stand by my original 5 star rating. I just made these again.  I still add a bit more milk but these crisp up so nicely & are delicious.

Original review: The only change I made was  by adding just a tad more milk because is is super thick.  I just eyeballed it both times but it was not more than a 1/3 cup for single batch and a double batch about a 1/2 cup.  Those who have mentioned them not crispy, I do not think it is due to the recipe. Mine have fluffed every time and crisped nicely.  I will say not all waffle irons are created equal.  For fun, the 2nd time I made them I tried almond extract instead of vanilla and just as good.  My family of 3 children who can be picky and eat very little. Finished these off! My husband and I only got a half of a waffle each, the first time. I learned my lesson and doubled it. It doubled nicely!! For doubling FYI 2/3 cup butter=10 2/3 tablespoons. So 1 stick  & just a bit of another. 

Update: With a double batch we had extra. We have frozen some & refrigerated some to see how they are next day or toasted in toaster.  They are perfect in the toaster!! Way better than the store bought frozen!!
 I'm not a big fan of breakfast for dinner, but this has served us well for a quick & yummy dinner.  We fried sausage links to go with & warmed some t

So, I rated this 4 stars only because I changed a couple of things ( according to reviews ), and did not have any vanilla extract. I added a couple tbsp. more sugar, and a bit more milk because the batter seemed a little thick. Also, I used a whole stick of butter. This was my first time making waffles from scratch, and I thought they turned out pretty awesome: crispy outside and fluffy inside. I made up extras, and took them to work for breakfast the rest of the week. One thing I am wondering is if self rising flour can be used in place of the flour/salt/baking powder? Thanks for the recipe, will definitely make again !

I used 1 c. All purpose flour. And 1 c. Wheat. I also added 2 tbsp. Of veg oil. 
 I whisked the eggs and sugar until frothy. Then added in the milk, butter and veg oil. In a separate dish I mixed the flour, baking powder, salt . Folded into the wet ingredients. Then folded in the vanilla.

text:
Yes I'm making this same recipe for waffles for over 12 years now. Make sure you use BAKING POWDER not Baking soda as what recipe called for.  One review from iAcademiaNut said she used baking soda that's why her waffles came out  soggy. 
I use buttermilk instead of plain milk texture and taste is way better.  For vacation s, I put Chico chips, peanut butter chips, blueberries, raspberries or mashed bananas. For toppings I make my own mixed berry sauce or powdered sugar aside from maple syrup

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677179.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These waffles are absolutely amazing! The only small change I made was extra vanilla since I love vanilla and alot of reviewers suggested to add more. Luckily I mixed my dry ingredients first before I started with the wet because I quickly realized I was going to have way too much batter for just me and my boyfriend. I took 1 cup of the dry ingredients and put in a zip lock bag for a future time then halved the butter, milk and eggs but kept the vanilla at a full tsp. Also to cut down time and dirty dishes to warm milk and melt butter separately, I just kept the milk in the glass measuring cup, stuck my butter in it and put it in the microwave together for 45 seconds. I plan on mixing up more of the dry mixture to store because these are definitely going to be a weekend staple!

text:
So yummy. I even modified it by changing flour to oat flour instead. I added more quick oats (no grind) for the chewy texture. It  makes denser waffles but I reckon healthier version as compared to this. This recipe itself is really perfect EXCEPT I think 4 teaspoons of baking powder is TOO MUCH. It makes the waffles taste bitter and 2 tablespoons of sugar are really not sweet enough too.. I used 2 mountain-full 2 tablespoons of brown sugar. I reduced baking powder to 3 teaspoons only. Tastes perfect!

There is definitely way too much baking powder and salt in this recipe.  I had my doubts but I don't generally know for sure how much to use. The waffles tasted like baking powder and salt . I was really craving them so I added a metric butt load of cinnamon, added probably 3 more tablespoons of sugar, another tablespoon of vanilla and about a cup more of milk to try and mask the taste.
Also using butter and syrup helped with the taste.
By themselves they're awful.
Smothered in sugar...theyre okay.

Display Name:
TheWhiteWolf

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614246.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I just bought a cast iron waffle griddle and was super excited to try it out.  This recipe looked like a good one to start with.  I halved it since I am the only one I'm cooking for.  Also, I discovered too late that I was out of vanilla extract.   I had some Almond extract on hand so I used that instead.  I like it so much that it may become the full time ingredient for me.  I preheated both sides of my griddle and oiled them well.  About half a cup of batter was what I needed to get a nice, full iron and still fit the lid on without batter oozing out the sides.  Two minutes on the timer for each side.  These were awesome!  Fluffy, full of flavor and a little crispy on the outside.  I am hooked!  I can see a lot of room to customize this recipe for different things and look forward to trying different things.  Oh, and with the halved recipe I got 3 full waffles.  I could only eat 2 of them so I wrapped the 3rd one and stored in the fridge for later.

text:
The batter was so thick, as in if I  could knead in flour I would have a pizza crust, or loaf of bread.  The waffles were so dense and thick.  Not sure what happened, perhaps because I used whole wheat flour?  It was white whole wheat, a wonderful King Arthur flour.  I also used skim milk, but do not think that would make any difference.  Anyway, if making waffles a bit healthier causes this outcome I am not interested in making this recipe again.  I will say, the vanilla extract was a great touch, I used good vanilla extract.

None
text:
My children love this recipe! We add 1/2 cup of ground chia seeds (in place of 1/2 cup flour). We use coconut/almond milk or 3.25% (whichever one we have in the fridge at the time) and it always turns out great. I always make a double batch and freeze them (pop them in the toaster, later!). Cool waffles on cooling rack, then divide with parchment or wax paper and place in large freezer bag.

Enjoy making this recipe with your children!!

text:
Just made this and I have to say it's the best waffle recipe I've tried. My 8 year old is the fussiest eater in the house and he finally approved waffles made by me from scratch, thanks to this recipe. I took others' advice and added a bit less salt, more sugar, a dash of cinnamon, and I separated the yolk and egg white. The result was  crispy, light waffles that were soft and light on the inside. A contrast to my normally hard, thick, dense batches. Now if only I could get my waffles to be the same color on both sides...( No fault of the recipe. Just my waffle maker.)

text:
I make these in a Belgian waffle maker, and they are very good.  I do up the milk to 2 cups, and up the vanilla to 1.5 teaspoons.  Other than that, I follow the recipe exactly.  Make sure your waffle maker is piping hot to get the crispy outside, and don't forget to spray oil or use cooking spray right before you pour in the batter.  I get about four and a half waffles out of this recipe.

We like these for school day mornings: they fill the tummy but aren't too chewy or heavy.  I used the recipe except that I separated the eggs, whisking the egg whites in their own bowl until soft peaks formed.   I combined the ingredients  but folded in the egg whites last.  These are come out like homemade Eggo waffles, crispy and light.

Best recipe out there and kids love it! Make almost exactly as recipe is given, but use another reviewers suggestions by upping total for sugar to 5 TBSP and Vanilla to 3 TBSP for a bit more flavored taste. I cut down the baking powder to 3 TSP, only because I’m not a fan of the after taste baking powder leaves and this eliminated that after taste.

text:
Delicious! I modified by adding 1 stick (no salt) butter, 5 tablespoons confectioners sugar (in place of regular sugar), 3 tablespoons vanilla extract, mixed all together with the other ingredients right in the blender and then I let my batter rest at room temp. for about 30min prior to cooking in waffle maker so that baking soda can react, making the waffles extra light and fluffy.

None
text:
This is best waffles recipe I have come across. I make it as directed, EXCEPT to soothe my guilty mom-conscious I put in only 1-3/4 cups of flour and add 1/4 cup wheat germ and 2 Tbsp of ground flax seed for a tiny bit of health factor. You can't even tell those additions are there. Oh, I also put 3 tsp of vanilla just because I love vanilla and want a little more of the flavor. The waffles always come out light and fluffy and delicious. I love eating these with fresh strawberries. Yum!

I made a batch of these specifically so I could freeze them and take them out to toast as needed.  My daughter has to get out the door earlier, and I like this recipe in that it's simple, quick, and healthier than the boxed alternative.  My batter was a bit thick so I added an extra 1/4 cup milk.  She loves them, and because she slathers them with butter after toasting, I substitute canola oil for the butter.

text:
I have this recipe in my favorites and have made it many times. My variations include real butter, when I have it but good if I don't, 1 tbsp lemon juice, this fluffs the batter, and 1/4 cup maple syrup, adds sweetness and flavor. We generally top them with margarine, cinnamon-sugar, jam, powdered sugar, and/or whipped cream. Pretty much, top them with whatever you prefer. Delicious! I agree with halving the salt and place them on paper towel to avoid sogginess.

Very solid recipe that produced fluffy waffles with just the right amount of crisp 'crust'. Surprisingly, I thought it needed more salt, which isn't something I ever say. text:
You can make these gluten free!!!! I use gluten free flour (pick a brand that already contains xanthan gum) and double the amount of sugar (per the suggestion of others).  I sift the dry ingredients together. I also separate the eggs (mix the yolks into the wet ingredients, whip the whites, mix the rest of the wet ingredients into the dry then fold the whites in). Perfect!

text:
I left a neutral review only because I had to comment on the critical reviews complaining their waffles tasted like baking soda.  There is NO baking soda called for it this recipe.  If you are using baking soda instead of the baking powder that it calls for then there is your problem.  Baking soda and baking powder are NOT the same thing.
I have not made this recipe, but I intend to and will review it when I do.

country:
None
text:
This is our go-to recipe when making waffles from scratch. Sometimes I add cinnamon for added flavor. I also use our own homemade vanilla extract. The only thing I do consistently different is separate the yolk and white. I beat the white until soft peaks form, and then once all the other ingredients are combined, I gently fold in the whipped whites. This makes the waffles fluffy, and is a tip I learned from my Belgium grandfather.

This recipe was the bomb. It was the perfect amount for me, my husband and father in law. we had scrambled eggs on the side for dinner. 

changes: I added an extra tablespoon of sugar and a half teaspoon of cinnamon. and the vanilla extract - I put the amount it calls for technically but as I poured it out i let it spill over the sides a bit to give it a little something extra. i used real butter and 1% milk. 

when they cooked it smelled AMAZING. And they tasted AMAZING. and we made ice cream sandwiches with the leftovers and it was AMAZING. 

im making these again!

None
text:
I used about half a cup of wheat flour and it didn't affect the fluffiness of the waffles at all and added to the flavor. Some of the negative reviews have mentioned the "too much baking soda." Just to clarify, the recipe calls for baking powder, not soda. Baking powder adds to the fluffiness of the waffles and has a relatively mild taste. Baking Soda, on the other hand, has a very strong taste and is usually used in only small quantities.

country:
None
text:
This recipe is absolutely amazing. I have been making these for about a year now and my kids love them. Decided to make them for out of town guests that I knew never experienced a "real" waffle before and they were in love! I do add 6 tablespoons of butter just make it easier and I love a more buttery taste along with an extra tablespoon of sugar.  To keep them from getting soggy, put them on a cooling rack when you take them out instead of a plate. The steam from the waffle not escaping is what softens them up. They also freeze amazing. Just take them out of freezer and pop them straight in a toaster.

Batter came out almost as thick as cornbread mix, and too salty. I only used half the salt so I was surprised. I think the butter ought to be unsalted for it to work, and I added water to thin it. Came out better. Also, I just checked about five other recipes and they called for no more than 1/2t salt, some adding only 1/4t, but 4t baking powder seems standard.

I'm usually a bisquick weekend waffle mom. This weekend I didn't have any bisquick so I tried this recipe. My variations include unsweetened almond milk, cinnamon, and a tbsp of brown sugar. I'm still unsure if I like this better than my usual box mix but it's definitely close. I'm sure it's healthier and more cost effective. It doesn't take much more effort to make. Coming from a box mix mom, this recipe is something simple and easy. Add syrup and fruit and the family will probably never know the difference.

text:
The waffles turned out crisp and light. I increased the sugar to 4 tablespoons and the vanilla to 2 tsp. I also added 2 tsp of cinnamon and a pinch of nutmeg. I separated the yolks and whites and folded in the beaten whites at the end as others have suggested although it didn't make much difference to the batter texture. This recipe made four waffles in my Presto Flip waffle maker (which uses 1 C of batter per waffle). Recommended recipe and will use again.

userID:
13927470
Display Name:
lunawriter
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
9
favoritesCount:
123
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674135.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made these waffles several times (almost every weekend now for the past month) and my entire family loves them. They come out crispy on the outside and warm and almost fluffy inside. They are one of the best waffles I've ever tasted. I can never go back to Eggo waffles again.

However, I did not give it five stars because the recipe does need several addendums to make it perfect. 


1/2 cup (1 stick of unsalted butter) total,
3 Tbls of vanilla extract total,
5-6 Tbls of sugar total,
1 tsp of cinnamon, and
separate egg yokes and fold in whites last.


Bear in mind, my tastes lean on using less syrup so I prefer a sweeter waffle, thus why so much added sugar. I tend to use one Tbls less when I add chopped strawberries to the mix. Fresh fruit really gives the waffles some zing! Also, if you're looking for a healthier edit, substitute 1 1/2 cups of whole wheat flour, instead of the 2 cups of flour. I attempted this once already and was very happy with the consistency and taste.

country:
None
text:
Made them twice. The second time I used what buttermilk I had left in the fridge in place of the regular milk (a  little over a cup, made the rest up with regular milk).  Both times turned out great. I took another reviewers advice and started by whipping the eggs in the blender, adding the rest of the wet, ingredients, mixing again, and then dry and blending just to mix. Made quick and easy work without a ton of mess. I also added about 4 tablespoons of sugar and 2 teaspoons of vanilla the second time like another reviewer had suggested. I increased the melted butter to 1/2 cup (whole stick). Nice bit of sweet.

userID:
17635335
Display Name:
d perey
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5655009.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made these now about 10 times and they are consistently good.   Good standard batter that is easy to modify to your tastes and easy to make.

Today I made them and this time separated the egg whites and whipped them up a little.  I then folded them in the moist batter.  This added a little more lift.   I also use this trick for pancakes.

I also added cinnamon and one peeled and diced apple to the batter.  I chopped the apple into about 1/4 inch pieces, so that they would not cook too quickly and turn to mush.
One apple provided at least one chunk of apple in every bite.  Before adding the apples, i sprinkled them w/ a little sugar and cinnamon.

I wish I could get the outside crisper with a custard texture inside.  Not sure if my iron is hot enough, of if that's a batter issue.  I use a Black and Decker iron w/ standard 4 square mold.

Anyway - taste great and easy to modify.  Its a keeper.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I immediately saved this to my favorites & will be making them again for sure. The only thing I changed was that I didn't use as much butter as it calls for & it was not missed. These are dense yet nice & fluffy with a slightly crisp outside. I also loved that the batter is thick enough that it didn't ooze out all over my waffle maker. A definite crowd pleaser! BTW, to the reviewers complaining of too much baking soda in the recipe, I must point out that there is NO Baking Soda in the recipe. It is Baking Powder, which will make a huge difference. Try it again with BP, I think you'll feel differently.

text:
I combined some of the suggestions from other reviews. This is the second time I tried this recipe. The first time I thought they were too much like a pancake in texture and not crispy like I prefer. This time around I used oil instead of butter, I sifted the flour, salt, baking powder and sugar together before adding milk (not warm like recipe says) egg yolks, vanilla. I folded in the egg whites last, and let the mix rest about 15 minutes while I heated up my iron. I also cooked them at a 2.5 setting (my iron has a light to dark setting range from 1 - 3). Turned out perfect!

text:
I did a few things different.  I'm lactose intolerant so instead of regular milk, I used soy milk. An other thing I did different was add one extra teaspoon of baking powder. It makes the waffles so much more fluffy and airy in the middle with a perfect crust on the outside. One last thing that I like to add is a 1/2 cup of cooked  oatmeal with cinnamon. It's delicious and much more filling. :) Oh and side note, I forgot the salt but it still tasted great!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great recipe.  I usually only make a half of recipe at a time as it makes the perfect amount for 4 waffles in our waffle maker (Cuisnart round maker).  I use whole wheat flour instead and add 2 tablespoons of ground flax seed to make it a little more "healthy".  Also, I increase the skim milk to 1 cup from 3/4 cup due to the added flax seed. To top the recipe off, add 16 Ghiradelli milk chocolate chips per each waffle once you pour the mix in waffle maker ("not healthy", but yummy!). Kids love "Dad's waffles"! It's become a Saturday morning breakfast tradition!

text:
I've made these a few times now and this recipe is definitely perfect classic waffles. I did notice they puff up more when you separate out the yolks as others suggested. I was lazy this time and didn't do it. I'm the only one who would've noticed that the top side didn't puff quite as much. I'm leaving a review to note that these are perfect if you reheat them in the toaster on the low-medium setting. Just let them cool completely then put in a zip lock in the fridge. Taste just as good the next day!

The batter looked very watery.  I was afraid I had done something wrong but since there were so many other positive reviews, I decided to just go with it.  I'm glad I did!  Perfect!  They fluffed up beautifully with a light crisp to the outside and perfect fluffy inside.  Great recipe!  Thank you!

This is a great waffle recipe. Sometimes when I am running out of time I use vegetable oil instead of butter. text:
I used this recipe this morning and my family loved them. I added some cinnamon to the recipe just because that is what my family likes. But they would have been perfect without the cinnamon too. I can not imagine this recipe coming out wrong unless someone didn't fully preheat the waffle iron properly. If your waffles are coming out unevenly cooked, you may want to let your iron heat while you are mixing everything up. I let my heat fro a good 15 minutes closed so the heat can evenly distribute across all sections.

None
text:
This recipe makes way more than 10-12 waffles. I've got about twice that now. I'll be freezing them for quick breakfasts next week. I added more oil and milk to the mix as it was too thick; about 1/3 of a cup more oil and 1/2 cup more milk, reduced the sugar and omitted the vanilla. I prefer my waffles to be the template upon which my toppings are the flavor. To each their own, though. My wafflemaker makes it easy to check the waffles, and if they don't have a nice honey-hue on at least 1/2 of the top, then the cover goes down for another minute or so.

text:
Love it I make it the night before because I have impatient toddlers and 3 kids total! I just refrigerate it and in the morning all I need to wait on is the waffle maker! We always more than double the sugar and I add chocolate chips. If you add the chocolate chips you need to wait because the warm milk & melted butter is enough to melt all the chips turning it jnto chocolate waffles which are great too but if you wanting chocolate chip waffles you gotta have the batter cool to room temp. I also have added frozen berries from Costco which the warmer the batter the better and those come out AMAZING if you love Bertie waffles! I have added peanut butter and bananas!!! So many great combinations!!!

city:

country:
None
text:
These waffles are delicious.  I made three changes.  I left out the butter and used Greek yogurt instead. (The spray I use on the waffle iron is more than enough oil so that the waffles come off clean.)  I also separated the eggs and beat the egg whites until stiff, then folded them into the waffle mixture as my last step before cooking.  Also, I substituted 1/2 cup of white flour for whole wheat, which didn't make a difference in the flavor, but made it a little healthier.  I also would recommend adding a little extra sugar or Splenda.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674167.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe worked flawlessly in my waffle iron, which I had previously stopped using because other recipes tended to fail miserably in it. The recipes and instructions which came with the waffle maker were kind of useless as they said to use pancake mix; this kept giving me weird, tasteless waffles or batter that overflowed out of the iron. This recipe was perfect! Waffles don't have to be messy! And, I don't think these took me much longer than regular pancakes would have. Maybe about 20 minutes more total since it used a couple more bowls and so cleanup was a bit of a bigger job, but not by much and these are definitely worth it! This batch even made enough so I have some to freeze for later! :D The only change I made to this recipe was adding maybe two or three tablespoons of hot coffee to top off my milk mixture when I ran out of milk. I'm tempted to keep making them this way as the coffee taste is really subtle but adds to the flavour. I may try adding some cocoa powder to a batch of these one day for chocolate waffles! Thanks for the great recipe. :)

text:
Wonderful waffles!! What kept it from getting a perfect 5 set of stars was presentation; mine never could come out as golden brown as the picture. Flavor-wise, it was magnificent! One waffle was enough to fill me up for breakfast, so I had quite a bit leftover that I wasn't expecting. To the lady who asked what went wrong: Baking POWDER is in the recipe, NOT baking SODA! Make sure you're following the recipe correctly before rating it so poorly next time!

Made this recipe today. My family loved these waffles.  I did make the following modifications. I used 3 tsp baking powder. I separated the eggs. Mixed the whites then gently fold in the yolks.  I used 3/4 cup warm buttermilk and 3/4 cup of regular warm milk.  4 tbl of sugar and finally some ground cinnamon. Very fluffy yet crispie waffles. Definately a recipe i will make again.

text:
This is my favorite waffle recipe so far.  I stopped looking for others finally after many different tries.  The difference is the fact that it's made with butter rather than oil.  
Though I add some cinnamon into my mix and a little more vanilla and it's amazing.  Making some right now in fact.  It's become a weekly or bi-weekly thing!
I've also tried with both salted butter and unsalted and it's best with salted and I really barely salt to it in that case.

text:
Great recipe as is.  I made a variation on this that I liked quite a bit.  Instead of using plaing milk, I used buttermilk.  Delicious.  But it only made 7-8 waffles.  Next time, I'll use buttermilk and double the recipe.  I didn't add any more butter or sugar.  The waffles are perfect without extra sugar.  Sometimes serve it with maple syrup, powdered sugar, sauteed fruit (in butter and brown sugar - e.g. apples, bananas, peaches, blueberries), or like today with leftover chicken fried steak.

text:
I made these two weeks in a row and they turned out great both times.  I did make this mornings with buttermilk instead of regular milk and they were very tasty.  My nephew said they were the best waffles he ever had.  I read some of the low reviews and I just have to say baking soda and baking powder are not interchangeable.  The recipe calls for baking powder and if you use baking soda instead you are not going to have good tasting waffles.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1018731.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Taste was really good.  There are a couple mistakes I think with the ingredients.  1 teaspoon of salt is way too much salt.  So, I only added 1/4 tsp of salt.  Also, I think there is too much milk added to it.  I added what was called for and they weren't as crispy as other recipes I have tried for waffles.  I think next time I will add 1 1/4 cup of milk and I might scale back on the butter too a little.  The batter was kinda soupy, and I know for a fact that waffle batter is thicker so I did add a couple tablespoons of flour to the batter.  Made it lots better.  Its a really good recipe but changing a couple things I will do next time.  I might even use vegetable oil instead of butter next time.  1/3 cup probably.

I mixed the dry ingredients together ahead of time (& added cinnamon) so I could wake up early and just add the other ingredients. Other than that, I've followed the recipe exactly. They turned out flat (not fluffy AT ALL) and bland. If they weren't still hot, it would've been like eating a brick. I think oil is best used in waffles instead of butter, but thought I'd give this recipe a try seeing as it has so many positive reviews. If anyone has enjoyed this recipe I'm certain it has been through their own minor tweaking.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/241182.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The flavor was decent, but they were too thick. I'm glad I tripled the recipe (my original intention was to have extras to freeze) but I barely wound up making over the original recipe serving size of 10-12 waffles. I got to 16 waffles that my children could not cut (and I barely could) and decided to stop being lazy and break out my tried and true BHG cook book and check the waffle recipe I USUALLY use. Come to find out this recipe doesn't have enough milk! For waffles that you can cut, have the same amount of milk as you have flour. I added some milk to the last bit of my batter and was able to finish out the bowl with some very delicious waffles. I would give this 4 or 5 stars if there was the proper ratio of milk to flour.

I thought it was odd that the recipe calls for 4 teaspoons of baking powder ... that's a LOT!  They had a funny taste to them and they would not crisp up, no matter how long I left them in the iron. They weren't fluffy either. Flat and a bit soggy with an odd, salty taste. I have read some other recipes that call for like 1 teaspoon of baking powder per 2 cups of flour. I will definitely try those recipes next time.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614247.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great, basic waffle recipe! I made just a few changes that I thought elevated these a bit. First, I use good quality baking margarine, but it has salt in it, so I eliminated the extra salt. I added two tablespoons more sugar to the batter and doubled the vanilla extract. I also added some cinnamon to the batter - yum! And lastly, give the baking powder some time to do its magic - after mixing all the ingredients, let your batter rest before making your waffles. Oops almost forgot -- if you aren't going to eat these right out of the waffle maker, don't stack them on a plate (even in the oven), or they WILL get soggy. Lay them directly on the rack of your warm oven to keep them warm and crisp until you serve them.

country:
