text:
TRY THIS ONE OUT!!! So took a bunch of people's advice: separated the eggs and whipped up the whites really well....sifted the flour, baking powder (used 2 1/2 teas), sugar (used 4 T), salt (used 1/2 teas), and cinnamon (used 1 T) all together....for the milk I made 1 cup of buttermilk (1 T of lemon juice and then fill it up to the 1 cup mark with milk and let sit for about 10ish mins) and then added 1/2 cup regular milk and warmed on stove...put all liquids together and then added to dry, whipped them all up then added the whites and cooked in preheated waffle maker and OMG soooo good!!! we loved them!! we only got 3 waffles from this...we also use whole wheat flour though so it makes the batter a bit denser...some people suggested adding more milk to thin it out a bit which I will do next time...

text:
This is my first time making waffles. I tried this recipe 10/7/12, following the recipe for 5 servings, but separated the eggs as mentioned by others. I guess it helped? I think a few more tablespoons of sugar and bit more vanilla will improve the taste. They weren't bad, just needed something extra. I intend to make a slightly bigger batch for next time since i was only able to make 3-4 waffles with my waffle iron as it requires a lot of batter to get an evenly cooked waffle. I only gave 4 stars instead of 5, as I believe the receipe is good, but I need more practice to adjust to my taste.

region:

country:
None
text:
I was serving my waffles with turkey and gravy and didn't want them sweet, so I cut the sugar in half and omitted the vanilla. For added fiber and nutrition, I used 1C less 1T white whole wheat flour, 1C less 1T white flour, and 2T soy flour. I separated the eggs and beat the whites and folded them in at the end as others suggested. They were very light and delicious, with much the same texture as the Bisquick waffles I loved as a kid. My picky kids preferred the boxed variety, but that might have had to do with cutting the sugar and omitting the vanilla.

5653591
Display Name:
Suze

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674134.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent waffles!!! I read all of the variations and came up with this. I whipped up the eggs in the blender first and then I added the remaining wet ingredients to the same blender. Make sure your blender can hold all of the liquid, I had to do it in 2 random batches. I transferred the wet mixtures to a large bowl and while stirring I added the sifted dry ingredients and stirred well. My ingredient adjustments were: 5 tablespoons of raw sugar, 2 tablespoons of vanilla, and 1 cup of melted real butter. I think whipping the eggs first made for a fluffy waffle. The batter even seemed fluffy. We served them with fresh blueberries, real maple syrup and/or honey. Enjoy!

text:
These were actually very good - I surprised myself. I don't easily give out 5 stars, so I'll explain why: firstly, the ingredients in this recipe are those that are usually in every kitchen. No rushing out to buy buttermilk. Easily adaptable by adding chocolate chips (REALLY good with these), nuts, etc. The only thing I tweaked was I added 5 tablespoons of sugar instead of 2. They crisped up nicely - some of the other recipes on this site did not. They cooked at a decent pace, too. Just a good, basic waffle that made for a great breakfast. Will definitely make these again.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674134.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Fabulous basic recipe.  My family thoroughly enjoyed it.  I like that it uses butter.  Those recipes that require oil leave a nasty taste.  I must say it tasted a bit bland when I followed the recipe, so the second time I made a few changes.  I couldn't stand the idea of my family having so much butter, so I cut the butter down to 2 TBSP, added 1/2 teaspoon of cinnamon, added an additional tbsp of white sugar and 1 tbsp of brown sugar (next time I'm going to try all brown sugar), and increased the warm milk to 1 3/4 cup to make up for the liquid lost in not using so much butter.  They came out delicious!  We enjoyed them plain without any syrup or anything.  My son is on his fourth or fifth waffle and he's only seven.

region:
None
country:
None
text:
These were a bit dense, but tasty nonetheless. I didn't sift the dry ingredients (used whole wheat pastry flour) this time, but will see if that lessens the density next time.  I whipped up some fresh cream with a tad of agave nectar and used grade A 100% maple syrup over the waffles.  Fresh sliced strawberries and blueberries really added a nice touch to these.  This recipe made more batter than we could eat in one sitting, but we used it all up and froze the leftover waffles in zip lock baggies for the next weekend. The were equally terrific a week later warmed in the toaster.  Truly wonderful!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Crisp and fluffy, these waffles are rad! They are great following the recipe as is, but I usually add an extra egg (result of forgetting I was halving the recipe and messing up on the egg count). It makes them extra fluffy on the inside and crisp on the outside, without an eggy taste. Experiment with more vanilla, or almond extract. Also, try adding in some cinnamon to taste, I want to say it was about a tsp, and it made these seriously the best waffles I had ever had anywhere! Try topping with brown sugar it melts into the butter and syrup!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674139.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
After testing s few waffle recipes we've declared this one our favourite. It crisps very nicely on the exterior while maintaining a chewy, not doughy, centre. I do add 1/4 cup ground brown flax seed to the recipe and substitute 1/2 cup of the white for whole wheat flour just to add some fibre. I don't feel this affects the texture or flavour at these amounts and don't need to add any extra liquid to compensate either. This has become the staple for 'Waffle Sunday', a tradition for 9 months since I came across this recipe, and nobody's sick of it yet! Final note: I double the recipe and freeze the rest for quick school morning breakfasts (pop in the toaster) and the kids also love them in place of bread for 'waffle sandwiches' in school lunches.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2009-03-15T08:46:24.833

text:
These are so good!  We'll never buy boxed again.  I took some suggestions, I upped the butter to 1/2 cup, 2 tbsp vanilla and 5 tbsp sugar. I sifted and separated :D  YUMMY!  I am going to freeze a batch and see how they hold up to reheating!  My DD asked "why" then tasted one and with big eyes said it was the best waffle she'd ever had, including some restaurant brunch waffles!  I always froze my own pancakes and thought why not waffles.  (Nothing like homemade to cut out as many genetically engineered foods as possible). My motive was no GMO's and no MSG, but that is lost in the FABULOUS taste and texture of these waffles!

These waffles are excellent. The following were the only deviations I made: 1. Melt a little extra butter to brush on waffle iron. 2. Separate the eggs. 3. Fold in the beaten egg whites last. The waffles are light, fluffy, and taste delicious.

I've been cooking and baking for quite some time, and to finally find a waffle recipe that is not only easy (and cheap!) to make but that also has a light and fluffy texture to it, is remarkable. I have also noticed that quite a few of the reviews for this recipe include some individuals adding cinnamon and perhaps chocolate chips to the batter before cooking the waffles themselves, and I have to say that its quite a nice addition. country:
None
text:
Very yummy.  I compared it to another recipe I had that used one cup each of all-purpose and whole wheat flour and two tablespoons of sugar but used buttermilk, which I didn't have.  So I followed this recipe but did use the cup each of all-purpose and whole wheat flour and added the extra sugar.  I don't think that they needed the extra sugar, they were almost too sweet but I like the flavor and extra goodness the whole wheat flour brings.  When making a large batch of waffles for my family I have found that laying them on a cooling rack and then moving them to a warm oven is the best.  These were by far the very best right off the waffle maker when they were extra crispy.  Thanks for the recipe!

region:

country:
None
text:
Excellent recipe with room for improvisation.  I whipped egg whites separately while mixing together the batter and folded them in at the end.  Instead of the full amount of melted butter, I used half and added a dab of applesauce to make up the rest.  I added several shakes of cinnamon as well as vanilla for flavoring, and only used half the salt.  The final product didn't scream "apple cinnamon" but had just the slightest hint of another layer of flavor.  Served with fresh whipped cream, these disappeared in minutes.

I made these this morning because I wanted waffles but was all out of mix. This recipe was (almost) as simple as using a mix. These were good waffles.  I might be a bit too picky.  I added 1/2 cup more flour, cut back the salt, added cinnamon, and I separated the egg whites, fluffed the whites and them folded them in at the end.  My children loved it and I loved the way this recipe was easy to work with.

text:
I made these waffles, but they are a little on the bland side.  Even though I added two extra tablespoons of sugar, cinnamon and an extra teaspoon of vanilla, it still wasn't very tasty.  However, I would suggest adding maybe a 1/2 cup of flour, two teaspoons of vanilla and maybe a 1/4 to 1/3 cup of sugar.

text:
I wouldn't say these are the best waffles but they were good and alot better than many I've tried to make before. I substituted 3/4 cup cream and 3/4 cup warm water for the milk and cut back on the salt and added a little more sugar. The leftover waffles froze well and tasted fine after popping it into the toaster oven.
